title: 113_hr2689
content: The Act may be cited as the "Energy Savings Through Public-Private Partnerships Act of 2014". The Energy Savings Through Public-Private Partnerships Act of 2014 acknowledges the benefits of private sector funding in addressing energy efficiency challenges faced by the United States. It highlights the potential savings from reducing Federal energy costs through performance contracts and utility energy service contracts, which can upgrade Federal facilities without upfront costs to taxpayers. Performance contracting allows for retrofitting Federal buildings using private sector investment, leading to energy savings, improved infrastructure, and reduced operational costs. The Energy Savings Through Public-Private Partnerships Act of 2014 recognizes the benefits of private sector funding for improving energy efficiency in Federal buildings. Performance contracts and utility energy service contracts can upgrade facilities without upfront costs to taxpayers, leading to energy savings and reduced operational costs. The Energy Management Requirements under the National Energy Conservation Policy Act are amended to include provisions for energy managers to explain why certain cost-effective measures have not been implemented. The National Energy Conservation Policy Act is amended to require reports on agencies' energy savings contracts, including investment value, guaranteed savings, and reasons for any unimplemented plans. The National Energy Conservation Policy Act is amended to include definitions for retrofit activities and energy consuming devices. Additionally, the authority to enter into contracts is expanded to limit recognition of operation and maintenance savings for modernized systems. The National Energy Conservation Policy Act is amended to allow Federal agencies to sell or transfer energy savings for funding contracts. The National Energy Conservation Policy Act is amended to define energy savings performance contracts and include the use, sale, or transfer of energy incentives, rebates, or credits. The National Energy Conservation Policy Act is amended to include the use, sale, or transfer of energy incentives, rebates, or credits from Federal, State, or local governments or utilities, as well as revenue generated from energy or water savings, waste recycling, or more efficient equipment.
